Fields.DialogueText: Zdravstvuyte, Kapitan.
It's good to meet you, Voroshilov.
Likewise, Kapitan.
There aren't too many Belles out there who are named after someone who's still alive.
It is certainly a... unique situation, Kapitan.
That is why my government has placed me on this ship, Kapitan. Kliment Voroshilov is a Marshal of the Soviet Union after all, so we must watch over the Comrade of the Fleet that shares his name.

Fields.MenuText: I hear Belles named after dead people can see memories from their namesakes when they dream...
I wonder if our Voroshilov can read Marshal Voroshilov's thoughts since he's still alive...
Marshal Voroshilov is one of Stalin's most trusted generals. I understand why you must monitor our Voroshilov here.

Fields.DialogueText: Yes, this is true. Voroshilov's situation is even more unusual, and we still are not sure how much of a mental connection she shares with Marshal Voroshilov. We must study her in more detail.
We still are not sure about that, Kapitan - but it is something our government is keen on figuring out. I have several experiments to run on Voroshilov, along with orders to monitor her regularly.
I'm glad you understand why my presence is required, Kapitan. We must watch her closely until we have a better understanding of how much she knows.
It would be a little more polite if you did not speak to the Kapitan as if I was not even here listening, Yuri Ivanovich!
Comrade Voroshilov, I do not mean to be rude. Unfortunately, the reality is that our government must keep a close eye on you until we determine you are not a security threat.
I assure you I know nothing, Yuri Ivanovich.
That is what I am here to confirm, Comrade Voroshilov.
What if it turns out that she really can read Marshal Voroshilov's mind? Then what?
That is not for me to decide, Kapitan. My orders are only to report what I see.
*ALARM*
Apologies for such a quick meeting, but I've got to get to the bridge. I think we've got Morganas ahead!
Da, Kapitan. Boyevyye stantsii!
@BATTLE
What is that mess of wires you've got there, Mr. Yuri?
It is experimental technology, Kapitan. It still has many problems to sort out, but scientists in Moskva assembled this device to help monitor the thoughts of our Voroshilov here.
I wish you would not speak as if I was some kind of laboratory rat, Yuri Ivanovich.
Well, in many ways you are, Comrade Voroshilov! There are not many other cases like yours. It could pose a huge security risk if you can really read Marshal Voroshilov's mind.
My loyalty to the Soviet Union is unquestionable, Yuri Ivanovich. I would never do anything to harm the state. Besides, I already told you that I cannot read his thoughts.
Perhaps, but even Marshal Voroshilov himself found many traitors who claimed to be loyal to the party.
We also can't rule out the possibility of you being captured by our enemies. Even the strongest can break under interrogation...

Fields.MenuText: Voroshilov can tell us if she ever starts sensing Marshal Voroshilov's thoughts. There's no need to monitor her.
It makes sense to monitor her thoughts, but don't worry - no one is capturing Voroshilov under my watch!
She's a huge security risk! Maybe we should just lock her up in the brig!

Fields.DialogueText: It would be nice if we could take her word for it, but it is difficult to trust anyone these days, Kapitan.
The Rusalki are capable of destroying whole fleets, so they could easily capture Voroshilov if they wanted.
It is a bit early for such a drastic measure, Kapitan. Let me collect more data so we can make an informed decision.
The situation is also complicated by the Neutrality Fleet arrangement. We cannot trust any of the foreign sailors on the crew. They are all collecting information for their own intelligence services.
We have to set aside our differences if we're going to defeat the Morganas, Mr. Yuri. There's no single nation with a navy strong enough to take them on alone.
I agree, Kapitan. As much as I dislike partnering with the Western capitalists, it is the only way the Red Fleet can rid our waters of the Rusalki.
This might be true, Comrade Voroshilov, but we do not have to trust them just because we fight alongside them.
In any case, I assure you that I have no ability to read Marshal Voroshilov's thoughts - so the only intelligence I can provide is whatever I see from the top of the conning tower.
Well, that is what we will confirm with this device, Comrade Voroshilov. These electrodes on your scalp will monitor various areas of your brain, and this box will record all the data.
I suppose there are worse things than being a laboratory rat.
*GUNFIRE*
Sounds like we've run into some Morganas! You'll have to show me how this device of yours works later, Mr. Yuri. I've got to get to the bridge!
Da, Kapitan! It is the height of modern technology. I cannot wait to look into that mind of hers!
@BATTLE
Voroshilov! Nice to run into you out here! I apologize that we've hardly had a chance to talk since I took command.
That is not entirely your fault, Kapitan. Mr. Yuri has hardly let me out of his sight since he came on board.
That's true. I know it's a difficult situation, but he's just doing his job.
Da, Kapitan. I understand, but it does make me feel like a prisoner being watched every moment of the day.

Fields.MenuText: You've got nothing to hide, so let's focus on our mission to beat these Morganas.
If it's bothering you, I can tell Mr. Yuri to give you a little more space.
We really have to keep an eye on you until we determine you're not a security threat.

Fields.DialogueText: Da, Kapitan. I would like to keep my attention on the mission, but Marshal Voroshilov is one of the most powerful men in the Soviet Union. They will be watching me as long as he remains in power...
I appreciate your concern, Kapitan. However, Mr. Yuri does not answer to you - his instructions come from a much higher place. There is little you can do in this situation.
Some Comrades of the Fleet see memories from their dead namesakes in their dreams, but this is not the case with Marshal Voroshilov and I. We share our name, but not our thoughts, Kapitan.
Being on a warship is stressful enough. If there's anything I can do to help, please let me know.
Spasiba, Kapitan. You seem like an honest person, so it is good to have you as an ally. Just be careful - honesty is not always the strongest trait among those who lead us.
Honesty usually wins out in the end, Voroshilov. Don't worry about me - you don't make captain without understanding a thing or two about how the world works.
Ha! Honesty will just get you thrown in the Gulag, Kapitan! That is how the world works in the Soviet Union.
*GUNFIRE*
Looks like we've got Morganas ahead, Voroshilov!
Da, Kapitan - let us show those Rusalki the power of our guns!
@BATTLE
*MACHINE HUMMING*
Do you feel anything, Voroshilov?
Nyet, Kapitan. I feel nothing at all.
As I explained, the device is measuring the natural electrical activity in Comrade Voroshilov's brain. To put it another way, the device is merely listening. The procedure is completely painless.
Physically painless at least, Yuri Ivanovich. We have been sitting here for 10 minutes already - is that not enough?
My apologies, Comrade Voroshilov - this is the first time I have run the device with a live subject.
A live subject? I am not a scientist, but if you have been testing your mind reading device on dead subjects, you have certainly wasted your time, Yuri Ivanovich.
That is not exactly what I meant, Comrade Voroshilova... please be patient.
Well, it has been over 10 minutes already - do we have any results yet?
Hmm... well, the device monitors brain activity and plots the data on a series of charts. So you can see that this chart here is a record of activity in the anterior part of her brain...

Fields.MenuText: I don't understand how this tells us whether or not she can read Marshal Voroshilov's thoughts.
I thought this device could read her mind. This data just looks like a bunch of numbers to me.
Aha! This data proves that she really can read Marshal Voroshilov's mind!

Fields.DialogueText: Well, yes... it is very experimental technology, Kapitan. However, this is the best we can do to capture her thoughts at the moment.
You are correct, Kapitan. The data is just a collection of numbers, but it does represent all of her mental activity over the past 10 minutes.
That is jumping ahead a bit, Kapitan. The data is only a measurement of her brain activity over the last 10 minutes.
So how does this get us any closer to understanding if she can read Marshal Voroshilov's mind?
There is no need for experiments, Kapitan! I have already told you that I cannot read Marshal Voroshilov's thoughts. What I know about him I read in the newspaper like everyone else!
To answer your question, Kapitan, we will also run tests on Marshal Voroshilov. If there are similarities in brain activity over the same period of time, that could indicate a connection.
I can't imagine Marshal Voroshilov would want to be someone's laboratory rat either...
He does not really have a choice, Kapitan. The orders for this investigation are coming from the absolute highest levels in the Party...
*ALARM*
Let's pull off those wires for now, Voroshilov! We've got some Morganas to sink!
Da, Kapitan! Watch this battle closely, Yuri Ivanovich - even a laboratory rat can bite back when provoked!
@BATTLE
What's wrong, Voroshilov? You look a little shaken up.
I... I had a dream last night, Kapitan.
Not a bad one, I hope?
I had a dream about... him, Kapitan.
Oh, I see...
I was him in the dream, commanding troops in Finland. The forest was covered in snow, and there was so much smoke - and blood... the smell...

Fields.MenuText: Marshal Voroshilov has been in all the papers about the fighting in Finland. Maybe they caused your dream.
So you really can read Marshal Voroshilov's thoughts!
It was just a dream. It doesn't mean anything.

Fields.DialogueText: Perhaps, Kapitan. The dream felt so real though - as if I was actually there...
I am still not sure, Kapitan. It was a strange dream, and I felt like I was actually there - that I was actually him - but I cannot remember any specific thoughts.
Perhaps it was just a dream, Kapitan - but it felt so real!
Maybe it was a dream and maybe it wasn't, but it still doesn't seem like you can really read his mind.
Da, Kapitan. It felt so real, but at the same time everything felt so... foggy.
Maybe you need to get more rest. I think Mr. Yuri's constant monitoring is starting to get to you.
I do not mind sitting while he runs his device, Kapitan. It is painless enough. After that last dream, though, I am afraid to fall asleep again...
*BOOM*
Rusalki ahead, Kapitan!
Looks like no one's getting any rest until we sink these Morganas!
@BATTLE
Mind if I join you for a meal, Voroshilov?
Not at all, Kapitan. Please have a seat with us.
Us? Who else are you dining with?
I'm Petty Officer Jones, Captain. I joined the crew at the last port call, so I'm a bit of a newcomer. It's a pleasure to serve with you. I was just chatting with Lady Voroshilov here.
Good to meet you, Petty Officer Jones. What's your role on the ship?
Officially, I'm a radio specialist, but I seem to be helping out all over the place since I came on board. I'm used to Royal Navy ships, so it's been an adjustment serving on a Soviet cruiser.
Petty Officer Jones has been telling me about life in Portsmouth in the United Kingdom. It certainly sounds... lively.

Fields.MenuText: Portsmouth isn't that different from Nikolayev where you were laid down. They're both busy port towns.
It's always good to meet new people and hear about life in different places, isn't it?
Why are you wasting time talking to oppressive capitalists?

Fields.DialogueText: She is not part of the ruling class, Kapitan. The only way to spread the revolution is to educate workers about the exploitative systems they live under.
Da, Kapitan - it is the only way we can spread the proletarian revolution across the globe.
Da, Kapitan - but the revolution has not yet spread to Angliya. The proletariat there still lives under the control of bourgeoisie capitalists...
Hmm... that's an interesting point - but I suppose politics isn't the best meal time conversation topic, especially when our crew is as diverse as it is.
I'm just a sailor, Captain. I don't care much about politics.
I see...
... but don't worry, Captain! None of that communist business applies in the Royal Navy, of course! I've sworn an oath to defend the King, after all!
The foreign sailors serving with us have so much to learn, Kapitan.
*ALARM*
I hate it when the Morganas interrupt a good meal! Politics aside, I think everyone can agree that sinking them is the only solution!
Da, Kapitan! I will prepare the guns!
@BATTLE
Although Lady Voroshilov does have some very interesting thoughts about us worker bees slaving away while the upper class pulls all the strings!
The last time was only two days ago, Yuri Ivanovich. Is it really necessary to run another test so soon?
Da, Comrade Voroshilov. We must constantly collect data. The more data we have, the more accurate picture we will have of your mental state.
My mental state? It is quite normal - as usual.
That is not what I heard, Comrade Voroshilov! I heard you had a dream of Marshal Voroshilov in Finland the other day. That is hardly normal, do you not agree?
What?! How did you hear about this? The only one I told about my dream was... the Kapitan!

Fields.MenuText: I didn't tell Mr. Yuri anything! He must have found out some other way!
It wasn't me, Voroshilov! He must have been spying on us when we talked on the deck.
Are you sure you didn't mention it to anyone else? I swear I never said anything to anyone.

Fields.DialogueText: It would not surprise me if Yuri Ivanovich already has a network of spies and informants watching my every move!
I cannot do anything on this ship without being watched liked a criminal!
I told no one else, Kapitan! I am sure Yuri Ivanovich has spies all over this ship...
Ha! I am glad you trusted the Kapitan with your little secret, Comrade Voroshilov! The Kapitan never said anything to me, but I do have eyes and ears covering every square meter of this ship.
You seem to get a perverse pleasure out of spying on others.
I suppose that is why I am so good at my job, my little Voroshilova! Now please - let me attach the electrodes so we can begin the data collection...
You disgust me, Yuri Ivanovich.
*BOOM*
Morganas again! I've got to get to the bridge. Get the guns ready, Voroshilov!
Da, Kapitan!
You are not going anywhere, Comrade Voroshilov - not until the we have finished collecting our data!
*MACHINE HUMMING*
@BATTLE
There's no one within earshot, Voroshilov.
Da, Kapitan, but we must assume we are still being watched by one of Yuri's spies.
I suppose that's unavoidable at this point...
I am being treated like a criminal even though I have done nothing wrong, Kapitan.
I understand your feelings. I have to apologize, but there's not much I can do about Mr. Yuri.
The captain is the one in charge of the ship, is that not true?

Fields.MenuText: I'm in charge of the ship's wartime mission, which is to fight the Morganas. That's all.
Mr. Yuri is operating under the authority of your government. I can't tell him what to do.
Of course I'm in charge of the ship! That Yuri is really starting to grind my gears!

Fields.DialogueText: It is difficult to concentrate on the war against the Rusalki when my own government is spying on me, Kapitan.
That may be true, Kapitan - but this ship is a long way from Moskva.
Perhaps you should have a word with Yuri to remind him of his place, Kapitan.
Mr. Yuri is still an official representative of a Neutrality Fleet government. As long as he doesn't interfere with the mission or safety of the ship or crew, there's not much I can say to him.
If that is the case, I will have to deal with him myself. I... expected more from you, Kapitan.
I'm sorry, but you know I'm still on your side. Did he find anything new with the data he collected the other day?
It was just another collection of meaningless graphs, Kapitan. I do not understand how they can claim that the device can record my thoughts when all it does is draw lines across a page.
Mr. Yuri claims there's some sort of science behind it, but I'm no medical expert.
When the data gets back to Moskva, the Party and intelligence services will see whatever it is they want to see. I would call that propaganda, not science.
*GUNFIRE*
Enemies ahead, Voroshilov! If you need to blow off some steam, let's blow up some Morganas!
@BATTLE
Where's Mr. Yuri?
I could not care less, Kapitan! He disappeared as soon as we docked. I am sure he is being debriefed by party members somewhere in town.
*FOOTSTEPS*
Petty Officer Jones! Welcome back on board. I hope you enjoyed a few days of shore leave.
Oh, uh... yes, Captain!
Hopefully you stayed out of too much trouble! I'm sure this little port town is nothing compared to Portsmouth though!
Portsmouth? Oh yes, Portsmouth! Haha - yes, this little town is nothing like Portsmouth... where I'm from!
Is everything okay, Petty Officer Jones? You seem a little... anxious?
Oh, um... just excited to be back on board the ship, that's all!

Fields.MenuText: You've got a lot of stuff in that bag of yours, Petty Officer Jones. Did you do some shopping in town?
So what exactly did you get up to during your shore leave?
Shore leave must not have been that interesting if you're so excited to get back to the ship.

Fields.DialogueText: Oh - you caught me, Captain! It's just a bunch of sweets! I have a horrible sweet tooth, so I bought up all the chocolate I could find.
Oh, I really like my whiskey, Captain! I have to admit that I don't remember most of my evenings, and my days were simply spent recovering in bed.
Well, I am just a busy worker bee, Captain! I'm happy as long as there's work to be done, and there's no shortage of work on Voroshilov!
Hmm... well, I hope the few days off were good for you. I'm happy to have you back on board, Petty Officer Jones.
Glad to serve with you as always, Captain!
*GUNFIRE*
Sounds like we have Rusalki entering the harbor, Kapitan!
*FOOTSTEPS*
Greetings, Kapitan! Looks like I made it back just in time for departure!
Hurry up and get back on board, Mr. Yuri. We need to get out there and sink a few Morganas!
Of course! Good to see you again too, Comrade Voroshilov!
I wish I shared similar sentiments, Yuri Ivanovich.
@BATTLE
Can you tell me more about the dream you had about Marshal Voroshilov in Finland?
I am not sure there is much more to say, Yuri Ivanovich - unless you want me to describe what the dead soldiers looked like.
Finland did not go well for Marshal Voroshilov - many of our soldiers were lost. Members of the Party have many questions about the decisions he made--
Those are questions I cannot answer! If you have questions for Marshal Voroshilov, I suggest you ask him yourself!
Mr. Yuri...

Fields.MenuText: I think Voroshilov is telling you all she knows.
Doesn't that monitoring device of yours record all her thoughts anyway?
It sounds more like you're interrogating a criminal than conducting research.

Fields.DialogueText: This is all research, Kapitan! If it was an interrogation, I assure you I would not be so gentle.
We all keep secrets, Kapitan. The challenge is discovering exactly what she is hiding.
I admit that the monitoring device has its limitations, Kapitan. Some things still require a human touch.
I have been cooperative so far, Yuri Ivanovich, but I do have my limits.
I still do not have the data I need, Comrade Voroshilov, so I advise you to share anything of relevance. Otherwise, I may be forced to discover exactly what your limits are!
Ha! Are you threatening me, Yuri Ivanovich? I hope the NKVD taught you how to swim...
*BOOM*
That must be another Morgana attack, Voroshilov. Let's get to the bridge!
Now please excuse us, Yuri Ivanovich. If you have forgotten, the Kapitan and I have a war to fight!
@BATTLE
I tried arguing with Mr. Yuri, but we just received orders from the Red Fleet to change course to Mariupol. There's nothing we can do.
Our purpose as a warship is to fight Rusalki, Kapitan. We should be searching for ships to sink, not sailing circles around the Black Sea, running science experiments for party members in Moskva.
You don't have to convince me, Voroshilov, but even a captain has to follow orders.
*FOOTSTEPS*
Greetings, Kapitan! I assume you just received orders from headquarters to change course?

Fields.MenuText: Yes we did. Now can you explain what this is all about?
How did you know that? Our communcations with headquarters are on a secure channel.
It was just Voroshilov at first, but now you're meddling with the operations of the entire ship?

Fields.DialogueText: Of course, Kapitan! I have always been completely transparent about my goals and methods, have I not?
You could say I was expecting to hear from headquarters around this time, Kapitan. Your channels are still secure though, so do not worry.
Meddling? I am working towards the same goal as you, Kapitan - an end to this bloody conflict.
Please get to the point, Yuri Ivanovich - why have we changed course to sail to Mariupol?
You are getting straight to business today! What a refreshing change in attitude, Comrade Voroshilov!
As you know, we are interested in how close your mental link is with Marshal Voroshilov. Our initial data from our monitoring device indicates similar brain activity in both of you.
So you have subjected Marshal Voroshilov to the same ridiculous monitoring as me? All to collect data for your meaningless graphs?
The similarities in your data cannot be ignored, Comrade Voroshilov. However, we are not sure what effect geographic distance has on your mental link with the marshal.
I have no mental link with the marshal, so sailing closer to him will achieve nothing.
That is exactly the hypothesis we are testing, Comrade Voroshilov - so let us collect the data once we arrive in Mariupol.
We've spotted some Morganas on the horizon - it looks like we're not going anywhere without a fight!
@BATTLE
We should be arriving off Mariupol shortly.
Da, Kapitan. I am sure the data Yuri collects on me will be inconclusive as always. I have not had another dream about Marshal Voroshilov since the last one in Finland.
It seems like it's not something you have any control over.
Da, Kapitan - and if I had control over it, I would certainly chose to stay out of the mind of Marshal Voroshilov. He is my namesake, but he has done terrible things in his life...
Be careful what you say, Voroshilov. This is a pretty deserted area of the deck, but I'm sure Yuri has his spies watching us.
I have nothing to hide, Kapitan.

Fields.MenuText: True, but they'll always be watching you as long as Marshal Voroshilov is alive.
Your dream about Finland means there is some kind of connection, even if you can't read his mind.
You could still be hiding the truth from me, Voroshilov. Maybe you know more than you let on...

Fields.DialogueText: Da, Kapitan. Even if he falls out of favor, he will always be a risk as long as he lives.
Maybe it was just a dream and nothing more, Kapitan. Dreaming of other people is common enough.
What would I have to gain from that, Kapitan? My only desire is to protect our ship and crew while fulfilling our wartime mission. I have no interest in the affairs of Marshal Voroshilov.
Hey, isn't that Petty Officer Jones by the railing over there? It's pretty dark in the shadows, but it looks like she has a radio...
Petty Officer Jones! What are you doing under this walkway with a radio?
Oh, Captain! I was just, uh... testing some spare radio equipment before I brought it back to the bridge.
Ah. Well, that's very diligent and considerate of you, Petty Officer.
Kapitan, do you think it is strange to test a radio so far away from the bridge?
What do you mean, Voroshilov? It's her job to maintain the radios.
*GUNFIRE*
Oh, Morganas on the horizon, Captain! Time to get to action stations!
@BATTLE
I didn't want to bother everyone with all the static and chatter, so I found a quiet spot under here!
Ah, Voroshilov! Mind if I join you?
Not at all. Please, have a seat, Kapitan. I was just having another good conversation with Petty Officer Jones here.
Greetings, Captain! It's always good to have an opportunity to chat with you.
Likewise, Petty Officer Jones. I hope that radio checked out okay the other day.
Oh, uh... yes, Captain! Regular maintenance and testing is what keeps everything in ship-shape and Bristol fashion!
Petty Officer Jones was just telling me about how she has been having trouble sleeping lately. She even had a bad dream last night...

Fields.MenuText: A bad dream? That's certainly an interesting topic to bring up, Petty Officer Jones.
What kind of bad dream did you have?
Having too many sweets before bedtime can disrupt your sleep.

Fields.DialogueText: Well, it just happened last night, so it was fresh on my mind.
I had a bad flashback of a battle on my last ship. There's no feeling more helpless than watching enemy shells land on your deck.
Eat sweets before bed? I never do that...
Didn't you say you had a sweet tooth when you bought all that candy at the last port call?
Oh yes, of course! I'm still very good about avoiding sweets before sleep, though...
So, um... you said you haven't had any bad dreams lately, Lady Voroshilov?
I am not one to dream very much, Petty Officer Jones - at least when it comes to nightmares.
Huh... well, I suppose it's good that you're such a sound sleeper!
*ALARM*
Seems like I won't have time to eat after all...
We will have to sink the Rusalki quickly so your food does not get too cold, Kapitan!
@BATTLE
It's nice to be back on dry land for a bit, isn't it?
I suppose it is for you, Kapitan. A Comrade of the Fleet can never stray too far from her ship.
Oh, that's right. If it makes you feel any better, this port looks pretty sleepy. I'm not sure there's much here to keep our sailors entertained.
Sailors on shore leave can always find entertainment, Kapitan - usually without walking too far from the ship...
By the way, do you think Petty Officer Jones has been acting a bit suspicious lately?
Of course she has, Kapitan. She is obviously a spy.
Ah. Well, I'm glad I wasn't the only one thinking that.
She is not a particularly good spy either, Kapitan. It is difficult to find motivated workers in capitalist countries like Angliya.
I'm not sure if it's a lack of motivation, but she sure does lack subtlety...
At least her ineptitude at espionage is a bit charming - and much more tolerable than that Yuri Ivanovich!
Speaking of which, Mr. Yuri better get back to the ship soon. I think I see Morganas attempting the harbor.
We might as well go and fight the Rusalki, then circle back to pick up Yuri. I'm sure his debrief by the Party will be even longer this time.
You're right. Politicians sure know how to spend hours talking about nothing. Let's get out there and sink a few Morganas while we're waiting, Voroshilov!
@BATTLE
I'm going to ignore what you almost certainly meant by that. But I wonder if there are any recruitment opportunities here.
In a place like this?
Just trying to stay positive.
A worthy effort.
So what did you want to talk about, Mr. Yuri? Do you need to run more tests on Voroshilov now that we've arrived at Mariupol?
Yes, that is exactly the plan! Since we are now physically closer to Marshal Voroshilov, we will set up the monitoring device and measure Comrade Voroshilov's brain activity.
Perhaps their link will be stronger with less distance between them.

Fields.MenuText: How can you measure their link when all your device does is draw a bunch of lines on a graph?
Has there been any conclusive proof that they have a mental link at all?
Why would physical distance matter if they have some sort of magical mind connection?

Fields.DialogueText: This is all new technology, Kapitan! I would not expect you to understand the details, but in a general sense, the more identical their graphs are, the stronger the mental connection.
The data we have collected is similar at times, but varies wildly at others. However, our sample size is still very small. We need to continue collecting data before we can conclude anything.
It is not magic, Kapitan! We are living in an age of science! Although I have to admit that science still has not been able to fully explain the Rusalki or Comrades of the Fleet...
You claim to be a man of science, Yuri Ivanovich, but you still have not proven anything between Marshal Voroshilov and me. Why must we continue these experiments?
My little Voroshilova, as naive as you are, I am sure you understand that I am just following orders from a higher authority.
Make it quick, Mr. Yuri. We've got a Morgana fleet approaching, so I'll need Voroshilov's full attention once the guns start firing.
Da, Kapitan - I will get started right away! Now place the electrodes on your head, Comrade Voroshilov - you know the procedure by now...
The procedure is as familiar as your lack of results, Yuri Ivanovich!
*MACHINE HUMMING*
@BATTLE
The last monitoring session went well, Kapitan! I will send Comrade Voroshilov's brain activity data to Moskva immediately.
I hope you got all the information you need, Mr. Yuri. I'd like to focus our attention on fighting this war from now on.
Both Marshal Voroshilov and Comrade Voroshilov are important players in this war, Kapitan. It is essential to continue monitoring them to ensure our security.
All I am concerned with is fighting the Rusalki, Yuri Ivanovich. If you would allow me to do this undisturbed, it would make a greater difference than sitting for your science experiments.
The war is not that simple, my little Voroshilova! Even our partners in the Neutrality Fleet are our enemies. We cannot trust anyone, including you, unfortunately!

Fields.MenuText: Voroshilov is committed to defeating the Rusalki and serving the Red Fleet. Nothing has ever indicated otherwise.
We have crew members from every Neutrality Fleet partner. We have no choice but to trust each other.
If we can't trust anyone, we certainly can't trust you, Mr. Yuri.

Fields.DialogueText: Perhaps, but she still poses a security threat for my government if she is captured... or if she ever changes her loyalties...
I had no idea you were so naive, Kapitan! There can be no talk of trust in a world carved up by empire.
My loyalty is to the Communist Party and the success of the Soviet Union, Kapitan.
We serve the same masters, Yuri Ivanovich. There is no reason to treat me like a criminal.
Even if I could trust you, there are spies among us on this ship, Comrade Voroshilov. Yes, it is true! I suppose you are oblivious to the fact that our enemies are watching your every move!
Oh, are you talking about the spy from Angliya - Petty Officer Jones?
You... you know she is a spy, yet you dine with her in the mess hall?
She is a terrible spy. It does not take much to confuse and misdirect her.
I cannot believe you are knowingly speaking with foreign intelligence agents, Comrade Voroshilov! Moskva will hear about this at once!
*ALARM*
Please go ahead and tell Moskva, Yuri Ivanovich! The Kapitan and I have more important matters to attend to - like defeating the Rusalki who are trying to destroy our ship!
@BATTLE
We know you are a spy, Petty Officer Jones. I am sure you were sent here by your government to keep an eye on me.
Why... what do you mean, Lady Voroshilov? I'm just a radio technician--
T-foo! You are a terrible actress, Petty Officer Jones - and an even worse spy!
Who is this gentleman, Lady Voroshilov?
This is Yuri Ivanovich, and he is hardly a gentleman. He is another spy, sent by my government. It seems that everyone wants to spy on me.
Oh... I see. So where does that leave us now?

Fields.MenuText: Since everyone on the ship is a spy, I suppose we can all be friends.
As long as you don't break any Neutrality Fleet rules, you can remain on the ship - but behave yourself.
I haven't quite figured out what to do with you yet.

Fields.DialogueText: That doesn't sound very likely, Captain. Mr. Yuri here doesn't seem like the friendly type. You're not going to do anything about me though?
It's not against the rules to have friendly chats with fellow crew members, Captain. I promise I'll keep it to that.
I haven't done anything wrong, Captain. It's not against the rules to write home every now and then to tell people how I'm doing...
You can't actively collect intelligence for your government while serving on a foreign ship, Petty Officer Jones. That's espionage.
There's nothing to learn about Voroshilov anyway. People were guessing that she might be able to read Marshal Voroshilov's mind, but that isn't the case.
The Kapitan is right, Petty Officer Jones. You can spy on me all you want, but no useful information will come out of it. Marshal Voroshilov and I are two entirely different people.
You will let this spy continue to serve on a Red Fleet ship? This is insanity, not to mention treason!
*BOOM*
Pardon us while we go fight the Rusalki trying to sink our ship, Yuri Ivanovich! That seems more important than politics at the moment!
Treason, Comrade Voroshilov! This is all going in my next report to Moskva!
@BATTLE
This is one of the few places where we can make sure we're not being watched, Captain.
What did you want to talk to us about?
Yuri Ivanovich is up to no good.
This is not news to us, Petty Officer Jones. You really are a terrible spy...

Fields.MenuText: Please excuse Voroshilov - she doesn't get along very well with Mr. Yuri.
What intel do you have on Mr. Yuri?
Mr. Yuri is just doing his job. There's nothing wrong with that.

Fields.DialogueText: I can't blame her, Captain! He's not exactly the friendliest person I've ever met...
Mr. Yuri poses a danger to all of us, Captain...
You can still do your job and be up to no good, Captain.
Please go on, Petty Officer Jones. It sounds like you've heard things about Mr. Yuri that we really need to know.
I wasn't lying about being a radio specialist, Captain - it's the main reason my government chose me for this mission.
I've been monitoring Mr. Yuri's nightly radio communication with Moscow. They speak in a lot of code words, but he's talked about the possibility of initiating what he calls "Course of Action B."
Whatever "Course of Action B" is, it must be worse than whatever he is doing now. So you are good to report this to the Captain, Petty Officer Jones.
I agree with you, Lady Voroshilov. I think the only way I can figure out what "Course of Action B" is involves breaking into Mr. Yuri's quarters to look through his notes when he's not around.
We are scheduled for another brain monitoring session later today. It usually takes 30 minutes at the least. That should give you enough time to look around his cabin.
*BOOM*
Sounds like a plan, Lady Voroshilov - but it looks like we might have to take care of some Morganas first!
@BATTLE
You are remarkably cooperative today, Comrade Voroshilov!
I have come to realize that this monitoring will continue no matter how I feel about it. I am also convinced you will never find anything of interest.
There are so many interesting things about you, Comrade Voroshilov - that is why we must continue to investigate!
I do appreciate your cooperation. I knew it was only a matter of time before you understood the necessity of my work.
I said nothing about your work being necessary, Yuri Ivanovich. I have only decided that arguing with you will not change anything.
This realization is enough to bring me a small amount of satisfaction, Comrade Voroshilov.

Fields.MenuText: Take all the time you need, Mr. Yuri.
Could you tell me more about how this machine works?
Do you really think Voroshilov can read Marshal Voroshilov's mind?

Fields.DialogueText: You are also being quite cooperative today, Kapitan! Moskva will be pleased to hear about this change in attitude.
Well, the electrodes measure the electrical activity in various regions of her brain. The data is collected over time and recorded on this film, giving us a picture of her mental state...
... it is rather simple in the end, Kapitan. We compare the data from Comrade Voroshilov and Marshal Voroshilov, and if they are identical, there must be a strong mental connection.
The data so far does show remarkable similarities at times, but also completely different states at others, Kapitan.
While I have no reason to doubt Voroshilov's claims, the data does demand further investigation.
We can sit here all day, Yuri Ivanovich. You can monitor me for an entire year if needed - but I assure you that nothing will come of it.
I hope that such a long amount of time will not be necessary. The more data we collect, the faster it will be to come to a conclusion.
Please, take your time, Yuri Ivanovich...
Spasiba, Comrade Voroshilov...
*MACHINE HUMMING*
@BATTLE
We stalled as long as possible during the last monitoring session, Petty Officer Jones. I hope you were able to find useful intelligence in Yuri's cabin.
Oh, I found useful intel, but it's not good news at all!
Well, there's not a lot of good news these days, so I think we can handle whatever it is.
Yuri has approval from Moscow to sink the ship if he determines that Voroshilov is a security risk! On top of that, he already has four bombs hidden in strategic locations in the ship!

Fields.MenuText: Is there any indication that Yuri views Voroshilov as a security threat?
I can't believe he's planning to blow up the ship!
We need to find Yuri immediately and lock him up in the brig!

Fields.DialogueText: I agree, Captain! Things are too risky otherwise!
It's hard to say, Captain - but he has full approval from Moscow to blow up the ship if he thinks it's in the best interest of the Soviet Union!
I'm not sure if he's decided to do it yet, but this whole ship is wired to blow at any time, Captain!
Voroshilov! We need to find Yuri immediately and lock him up in the brig. We also need to find these bombs before he or one of his lackeys on our crew decides to blow us to the bottom of the ocean!
Da, Kapitan! We finally have enough evidence to lock up that annoying little man...
You do have evidence of all this, right, Petty Officer?
Yes, Captain! It's all laid out in official correspondence I found locked up in Yuri's cabin. I photographed all of it as evidence.
Well, locking up Yuri would put us directly against the orders of the Soviet government - but the safety of the ship and crew is my primary responsibility as a captain.
You won't have time to worry about a court martial if you've sunk to the bottom of the Black Sea, Captain!
*GUNFIRE*
Ah, hell! This is the absolute worst timing for a Morgana attack! Let's get moving, Voroshilov!
@BATTLE
This is a huge fleet of Rusalki, Kapitan! Even if we manage to sink them all, it will take some time!
We don't have much of a choice, Voroshilov! We need to take care of this fleet of Morganas and find Yuri's bombs before we're out of danger.
Da, Kapitan!
Captain! I found one of Yuri's bombs hidden at the base of the conning tower! I've already got a team of engineers working to disarm it!
Good work, Petty Officer Jones! So there should be three more bombs to find, right?
That's right, Captain. We still need to find Yuri and lock him up too!

Fields.MenuText: Where do you think Yuri placed the other bombs? In among the munitions?
Yuri must have seen the engineers disarming one of his bombs. He's probably in hiding now...
Voroshilov, I need you to concentrate on fighting the Morganas while we take care of Yuri!

Fields.DialogueText: Nyet, Kapitan! The crew can handle the Rusalki. It is personal between Yuri and me now - I will help you find the bombs and that little rat!
It seems an obvious location, Kapitan. Perhaps too obvious...
We will find him eventually, Kapitan. I would love to throw him overboard, so he should feel lucky if we just lock him up instead.
We need to get moving. Now that we found one of his bombs, Yuri might be tempted to set off the rest.
Da, Kapitan - but we have more Rusalki approaching, and it does not look like an easy fight!
@BATTLE
It sure is a mess of pipes in this engine room, Captain! Soviet engineering is crazy - if Yuri hid a bomb down here, it could be anywhere!
My engineering is based on Italian plans, so please give credit where credit is due, Petty Officer Jones.
My apologies, Lady Voroshilov - I'm just skeptical about finding a bomb around here anytime soon...

Fields.MenuText: I'm sure if we all work together, we'll find it soon enough.
There are a lot of pipes, but there are only so many places Yuri could have hid a bomb.
We have to find this bomb - otherwise we'll find ourselves on the bottom of the ocean!

Fields.DialogueText: Good to keep a positive attitude, Captain! Let's find this thing!
Good point, Captain. If it's the same size as the one we found by the conning tower, it's probably on the floor, tucked behind something pretty big...
You're right, Captain! Now's not the time to doubt ourselves...
A bomb the same size as the one on the deck should be easy to find, Kapitan.
Right. It's got to be too big to hide above us, so let's check the corners behind the turbines...
Oh-hoh! Good guess, Kapitan! Here it is behind the second turbine!
Great work, Voroshilov! Petty Officer Jones, get another engineer team down here to disarm this one. Voroshilov and I will keep looking for the others.
Aye-aye, Captain!
*BOOM*
Sounds like the Rusalki are still attacking, Kapitan! We'll have to take care of them first!
@BATTLE
Here is the third bomb, Kapitan!
I can't believe Yuri would put a bomb in the mess hall! He clearly isn't concerned about killing the entire crew along with the ship.
We are all just numbers to the leadership in Moskva, Kapitan...

Fields.MenuText: How can you support a government that wouldn't mind seeing you dead?
Sinking your own ship isn't going to help the war effort...
I suppose the ends justify the means...

Fields.DialogueText: They... they want to spread the revolution - but I wish it did not involve getting rid of me...
This is true, Kapitan. The Red Fleet already needs more ships than are available.
Perhaps in the right circumstances, Kapitan - but I promise you that sinking this ship will help no one!
Let Petty Officer Jones know we've found the third bomb. We need an engineer team in here to disarm this thing as soon as possible!
Da, Kapitan!
I wonder where we'll find the last bomb - and we still need to find Yuri too...
I have a feeling we will find both soon enough, Kapitan!
Either that, or Yuri will try to sink us with the last bomb he's got!
*GUNFIRE*
There are still more Rusalki within range, Kapitan!
Seems like we're a target for everyone these days, Voroshilov! Let's sink these Morganas before they do too much damage!
@BATTLE
You've got to be kidding me! You've got the gall to be standing on my bridge after planting bombs all over the ship?
Yuri Ivanovich! I cannot wait to throw your disgusting body overboard!
Seems like you have found out my plans, Kapitan! However, I cannot let this dangerous security threat continue!
The data indicates that Comrade Voroshilov has some connection with Marshal Voroshilov. It would be foolish to allow Comrade Voroshilov and this ship to keep sailing with the Neutrality Fleet!
You've said yourself that the data is still uncertain, Yuri! How could you do something as crazy as blowing up your own navy's ship?
I would like to err on the side of caution, Kapitan. Moskva has given me full authority to make a decision. To be honest, this ship is nothing in the grand scheme of things, and will not be missed.

Fields.MenuText: We're going to lock you in the brig, Yuri. I don't care what Moscow thinks.
You really want to make a decision like this based on incomplete data and gut feelings?
The Red Fleet needs all the ships it can get. It's already in a pretty sorry state.

Fields.DialogueText: The war will be won on land, Kapitan. The Red Fleet is just for keeping up appearances with our rivals.
Ha! You do not understand how much trust and support I have among the Party in Moskva, do you?
The risk that Comrade Voroshilov presents outweighs any benefit she could provide to the war effort, Kapitan.
*FOOTSTEPS*
... Captain! We've disarmed all three of the bombs we've found so far, and only need to--
Oh-hoh! The amateur British spy! I hope you found all the notes in my cabin interesting during your little break-in the other day!
You sure are a confident one, aren't you, Yuri?
I have full authority from Moskva. You can't touch me.
I've got full authority from the Royal Navy, Yuri. This ends here.
A gun? You are full of surprises!
Please escort Mr. Yuri to the brig, Petty Officer Jones.
Aye-aye, Captain!
More Rusalki on the horizon, Kapitan!
@BATTLE
Yuri said the last bomb should be hidden somewhere around here, Captain.
How'd he give up that information so fast?
I gave him a bit of... persuasion, Kapitan. He broke surprisingly quickly.

Fields.MenuText: Cowards like him usually do.
I'll promise not to report this to Moscow.
I hope you didn't leave any bruises...

Fields.DialogueText: It never even got that far, Kapitan. Yuri is nothing but a rat!
Da, Kapitan. He talked big until we dangled his feet over the water...
Spasiba, Kapitan. Although loyalties in Moskva change faster than the winds. It is possible that nothing comes out of this.
Sorry to interrupt, but it looks like we've got some stragglers from that last Morgana fleet, and they look ready for a fight!
I do not mind sinking a few more Rusalki, Petty Officer Jones!
@BATTLE
Thank you for your help with Yuri, Kapitan. Through this whole ordeal, you are the only one I could always trust.

Fields.MenuText: Of course you can trust me! Taking care of you is part of my job.
From the moment I saw you, I knew I would do anything to keep you safe.

Fields.DialogueText: I am truly lucky to have such a responsible kapitan!
I... I'm lucky to have someone so brave and strong by my side, Kapitan!
I hate to interrupt again, but we still need to find that last bomb!
It should be around here somewhere...
Kapitan! Could that be it by your feet?
Huh, that doesn't look like a bomb to me, but I suppose you could be--
*BOOM*
Kapitan!
